chSEexWcuLhbQzHy5jtZGg.text: Good food, some nice veggie/vegan options too! Nice smaller-scale alternative to Wagamama!

KXm79dFs4ScGM7UijlJROg.text: The seems to be a very trendy restaurant in London.   The interior is done well.  I was really excited to try the Asian fusion style food.  We ordered 3 dishes and none seemed to be fusion.  They were close to Chinese in my opinion.   The presentation was done very well but the overall food was just OK.   Everything looks amazing but I was not feeling the taste or was not impressed by any one of the dishes.

qwmrxHwSNIAv3L_HuAoe7g.text: Following in the footsteps of other 'alright to like it' chains Wahaca, Byron and Cay Tre, The Banana Tree Canteen has opened its doors on the lucrative corner of Old Compton and Wardour Street. They've stripped back a relatively new concrete clad build to reveal, surprise shock horror, a bland concrete interior, complete with a ceiling full of air con and shiny piping. Unnecessarily New York.The menu takes you on an interesting twirl round Indochina, an accurate description, if slightly colonial and not a word you hear oft used to describe the Thai / Viet / Malay cuisine on the short snappy list. Like trailblazing neighbour Busbai Eathai (they of the legendary hour long post work queues) it's aimed squarely at the office crowd. There's a good mixture of sweet and spice, nothing too challenging, and you'll get away for £25 a head, perfect for that leaving lunch or a postscript to a few drinks.A selection of mainly fried dim sum style starters thankfully feel homemade, or at least freshly made, and skip the sacherrine sweet MSG chilli toilet cleaner that often accompanies such dishes. We pulled little morsels of salty porky flesh from their bones and hoovered up moist and juicy minced chicken 'moneybags'  deep fried in bulbous wonton wrappers, pleasingly large, and definitely more than Monica from HR could cope with in one mouthful. Steamed dumplings were sadly less successful. Waterlogged, still born gzoya in an acrid burnt sauce.Mains were pleasingly meaty, coming in two principle variants  the marinaded to dark almost bitter perfection meat, a char-grilled blackened chilli pork and a blackened beef both fell into this category, or the softer strops of al dente noodle curled round various sauces. The meat arrived punctuated with pillowy mixed vegetable rice and more dipping sauce, they had enough heat for the casual chilli hound, though not enough for me, lacking as they did the kick from the missing, surely obligatory, bottle of Sriracha sauce.Cocktails are a bit of a let down sadly, in an All Bar One kind of way. Overkill of nutmeg gave (too much) Oriental flavour to a watery Mai Tai and the freezer cold lychees in a second were just nasty. That being said, I'm sure I'll be back, it's a sufficiently above average offering in an everyman kind of way and sometimes frankly, only a Thai can satisfy.

JqIavTKhqsW56i7_Qy969Q.text: YUM!  Reasonably priced and amazing food.  Get the traditional staple curry dish and the duck.

4H7nelMJvELrAGfugd66Pg.text: Not too bad! I think this place used to be an Itsu ... or some conveyor belt sushi place, if not Itsu. I went there about a year and a half ago. Then it closed. Now it's a Thai place. Not sure how long it's been open or why you would care so much about these specific details of my visitation of this establishment.I went with a work group - eight of us, and I was paying - and we were able to get a table without much issue. Initially seated at a table in the middle/back of the room, our seats were stools without backs. I have the posture of a slouching primate, so I was a little disappointed. But, to our luck, we were moved to a table with proper seats. Oh glorious day!I ordered the green curry with some jasmine rice. It was alright, nothing too special and not exactly prepared in a traditional style. But, it was decent - I won't complain. I had a good mocktail, too. Something with lychees in it. And I learned the word mocktail. That was a new one to me! I am so bringing it back to the US. Look out, world. I've got a new word and I am so using it.

VCGhxfpSLnprKLGZlFytHg.text: I popped in here for a bit of post Dr Who dinner on Saturday evening with a friend, and we were seated very quickly which my poor tired feet appreciated greatly. I quite liked the spartan decor but after that I was not best impressed with the experience.We arrived barely after 10pm, and my friend ordered a cocktail only to be told that they were not making any! this after a cocktail specific menu had been put on our table, which I found more than a little odd. We ordered wine and our meals, which were served very swiftly, but mine was at best Luke warm. It was tasty, but particularly greasy and the temperature was a huge issue to me. I can only imagine food is precooked and reheated, or heated - sort of....What really left a bad taste in my mouth was a particular staff member who when lifting the bill and cash asked if we were expecting change, which is A) cheeky B) disconcerting. And the real kicker is that there was £18 due back to us and there is service charge included!!!!! I'm generous but a 75% tip is just a wee bit much for even me. It just really soured the experience and I left far from happy.

Ls1DygE_rp6iAUZ8f4PVeQ.text: I really like the lunch special, which comes with salad with a lovely, piquant dressing (I get it without the crushed nuts, thank you very much). The chicken with basil had a delicious, spicy sauce, although I was a bit distraught by the surplus of black fungus. Still, can't beat the price, especially in Soho.

rhrLq8TFikNn0nNS0wmEjw.text: - next tube station: Picadilly Circus (Picadilly Line)- crowded restaurant with tables placed very closely to each other; very noisy (you almost cannot understand each other at one table)- friendly staff; quick food delivery- they offer a selection of dishes and specialities from the Indochina region, the lemongrass growing countries of South East Asia that include Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand and the peninsula of Malaysia and Singapore- Street Style Crispy Dough: a light and chewy Indochinese style dough served with their signature Kajang Satay sauce (3.70 GBP); yummy, however, is it really light - deep-fried dough??-  spicy green papaya salad (5.90 GBP); spicy and tasty- char grilled blackened chilli pork: slices of leg of pork in aromatic dark soy, palm sugar, chilli, garlic & ground spices; served with oriental chilli and mango salsa (8.90 GBP); although I am not really a fan of pork it was really good (if you like your meat with sweet aroma)- drink "Princess of Ragnoon" was delicious! Recommended!Conclusion: Food was yummy, location is okay (very crowded, very noisy, very cramped)

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Spicy Green Papaya Salad

9zmrpWSSTt0kHWdNfrfTTw.text: It always makes me feel sad to leave a poor review especially when the staff are sweet,  but it really was a comedy of errors when we came here.  Firstly they'd lost our booking despite two confirmations. Service was slow, bathrooms untidy and the menu uninspiring for veggies. The crispy dough starter was sadly bland and deep fried (even though I'd asked and been assured it wasn't.) The sweetcorn fritters were good though. Not much else to add :(

agJNUJpwxanbHgTg9tqNqA.text: Stopped by this branch of the Banana Tree following a comedy show at the nearby Soho Theatre. This location can get extremely busy if you try to get seated around 19:30-20:30, but we arrived just after 21:00 and we were immediately given a table. This is a well located branch of the restaurant and we had visited before because it offers great value with a Tastecard, where diners were offered a 50% discount on their bill without making any reservation. However, after we were seated, we were informed that this branch is no longer accepting the Tastecard. The waitress clumsily advised us than we would still get a 2 for 1 deal on our main meal- this turned out to not be the case- or we misunderstood- as we were provided with a voucher with our bill for this offer on our next visit. Much to the credit of the management, I complained about the confusion and they let us use the voucher on our meal.Aside from the disappointment of losing a great discount with the Tastecard, the Banana Tree is reminiscent of Wagamama in both its setting and style- lots of communal seating and fast pan-indo/asian dishes that come out as they're ready. I personally prefer the food at the Banana Tree to Wagamama and feel you get a lot of value from their main meal upgrade option with rice, prawn crackers, corn fritters and a salad to accompany your main dish. The food always looks fresh and pretty healthy with a generous variety of vegetables- a lack of veg is something that has disappointed me in the past with Wagamama! The flavours are good, consistent and the staff are usually very prompt and friendly. This is a nice alternative to the other similar establishments for a quick and satisfying bite.The only issue we seem to battle with upon each visit is the proximity of tables to neighbours- we always have the misfortune of being placed next to a rowdy and obnoxious group and you literally can't hear yourself think over their conversation. This isn't atypical in these types of restaurants, especially in central London spots- I have just remarked it repeatedly at this location.Shame about the Tastecard discount being pulled, but it does appear that they are trying alternative in-house discounts and offers to customers, so watch this space.

wGSg7RrX8L_GNPU0qMyEYw.text: While walking around Soho with an American friend of mine, eager to show some of the culinary delights of the West End to her, we happened upon Banana Tree.Admittedly, it was a tossup between Banana Tree and Busaba EatThai. My friend and I were having a conversation while perusing the area's restaurants about trying new things and being open to new experiences. This is what swung it for me to try Banana Tree. I wish we had gone to Busaba.I did enjoy the buzzing atmosphere here, even on a Sunday evening. However, this is certainly not the place to come for an intimate evening of fine dining. We were greeted by our waitress and took a seat. After a brief look at the menu, I opted for the barbecue style pork with rice and my friend went for the Laksa noodle soup with prawns. To drink, I had a Banana Tree daiquiri with Raspberry and she had a lychee-based drink.The drinks arrived  and I did feel a little hard done by in that there was barely any alcohol and barely any fruit juice for that matter. It seemed to be a glass full of ice with a little fruit juice for colouring.When the food arrived, I was more than happy with the presentation and taste of my pork dish. However, my dining companion noticed that a number of her prawns were not de-veined meaning that they were essentially offering her "poo filled prawns". Our well meaning but linguistically inept waitress had a lot of trouble understanding what my friend's complaint was but eventually took the bowl back to the kitchen.During this time, a rowdy table full of diners joined. In such a open plan dining room as this, before long the volume level was approaching a din. that aspect was not so bad, however, the fact that they kept on shopping chairs and walking around meant that my dining companion was constantly being bumped into and having her chair kicked.Eventually the bowl appeared again and all that they had done was remove some of the prawns. And you guessed it, it just meant that there was a bowl of noodles soup. My friend did attempt to explain this again to the foreign waitress, but to no avail.At least, they did take it off the bill but unfortunately my friend went hungry for the time being.Overall, I enjoyed my food a lot however seeing what a painful process it was for my fellow diner tainted even the tasty food for me.

nTK703baVRh32cfAcFJQcg.text: I love this restaurant because the noodles are always excellent.  I had rice noodles with bean sprouts, oyster sause and prawns which was very tasty.  My friend had stir fried Singapore rice with egg which was a bit overcooked so it formed a clump.  However, it was still very tasty.For desert I had sweet black rice and my friend had banana fritters.  The banana wasn't very hot and it was served with chocolate sauce which didn't really compliment the fritters.The service was excellent from all of the team.  Banana tree offers good consistant cooking so I recommend this restaurant.

Pg5sBVGpZDjVnwptWMlgfQ.text: Boring Pan Asian fusion food. Jack of all trades, master of none.Manager relegated us to the back of restaurant instead of seating us on the large middle table that is available for groups. Probably due to the way some of us in the group were dressed. Thankfully our waitress was lovely!Typically with these sorts of fusion restaurants you're served a watered down version of an existing dish. The food wasn't terrible, but a far cry from the more authentic restaurants dotted around the same area. Also way overpriced for the sub-standard food.Wouldn't recommend.

Jbp9UqzH9onbd_9v7atScw.text: My friend and I who are Soho regulars chanced upon this South-East Asian restaurant and latest edition to Wardour Street last week and although it was busy and we hadn't booked, we were squeezed in. The food was delicious, we shared the Chicken & Shitake Money Bags and Kau Chi Dumplings for starters and considering they were starters, the portion sizes were generous. For mains it was even more difficult to decide as a lot of the choices sounded amazing, we both decided to have the Seafood Kari Santan Melayu which was a mixture of seafood, mainly prawns (my favourites) in a beautiful sauce. To drink, we both had a red wine each which was okay but nothing particularly special. The prices are really reasonable especially considering the portions are generous and delicious, the only reason this doesn't get a four star is because the service, although friendly, is really slow - from start to finish - which is a real shame and let down to the place.

fKreadHrTUY3Svtmua1dFw.text: Ok, so, I think this might be my first 1* review. And from the looks of it, I'm alone on how awful this place is. Lets recount the night so at least you can understand why. My friend and I usually do noodle night once a month. Last month was at Cha Cha Moon, and this month was supposed to be Ramen Seto, which apparently just shut probably no more than a week ago =`(. Anyway, on the hunt for noodles in soho, and certainly not desperate enough to go to the Lexington Street Wagamamas, we set off to Banana Tree.First off, Banana Tree did not pass the "Asian Test". I was the only Asian in the restaurant all dinner long. That should have been a bad sign having walked into the restaurant. And, the funny thing is, I didn't even realize it. My dinner date was the one who mentioned it to me! So, anyway, not minding the fact that we were both ravishing, we sat to order. He calls for a Fried Kway Teow and I go for a Singapore Mee Goreng. I guess I have to now divulge the fact that being Singaporean, I have high standards if you call something Singaporean. But, would you, if you were say French, have higher standards for French cuisine in England?! Okay, getting off the soap box. I should have taken pictures of it when the food arrived, but Fried Kway Teow and Mee Goreng are HIGHLY different dishes in my book, but dinner date and I were perplexed at why they looked so similar. It's basically the same dish, but his supposedly had Kway Teow in it. Now, this, this here is the main reason why this place gets a 1*. DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES CALL A DISH KWAY TEOW IF YOU ARE USING PHAD THAI NOODLES INSTEAD. Phad Thai noodles are thinner than Kway Teow and INSTANTLY noticeably different. It's like calling Plaice, Haddock and attempting to sneak it by. It's all fish right? WRONG. Ok, another reason why it's 1*?! They used the same bloody paste to make Mee Goreng and the Kway Teow. Mee Goreng paste is redder and usually spicy - due to it's Malay/Indian heritage. Not black sauce based. Redeeming qualities (but never enough to pull it out of 1*) are the cute waiters, the service, the phallic dangling lights over bar tables and the speed in which they fling you outta there. Next time, Cha Cha Moon over Banana Tree ANYDAY.

yJLbuw4xoPFk_fR7O7i9lg.text: I popped in after reservations at another place fell through. At that point in the night the other member of my party and me were getting pretty testy. Between being hungry and tired, I was resigned that this would just be another lack luster meal at a chain restaurant. Boy was I wrong! I ordered the Char Grilled Blackened Chili Pork and the Nasi Goreng Rice. They were delish! I don't remember the name of the drinks I got, but again, I was pleasantly surprised at the quality for the price. I would highly recommend it. In short- it's quick, tasty and well-priced! I'll be back :)

SFjax_ZPKnx0-6Qm84tUlg.text: I love the food here! It's well priced and the service is great. Occasionally I ask to not pay the optional service charge to see whether they are genuinely giving good service. I have never once been given bad treatment after this request here. The staff are great! I bring my friends here a lot for this reason.

GGs5-fEkMTCO2SKQ-mO7MA.text: Went here recently with a friend. What an awesome place!! Its got an industrial feel to it with canteen style tables (they've got 'proper' ones too), an open kitchen and a fab menu. We ordered sweet corn cakes - well balanced and fried crispy but not too heavy. Then I got the Beef Rendang - not the best out there but a very good one at that. Friend got the tamarind fish dish and cleaned her plate well.The place gives you the option of making your curry into a special which comes with plain rice, sweet corn cakes & a salad on the side. Great option for the money.Best part, they also serve booze and my favorite drink their 'Dirty Thai Guy' - That name, Captain Morgan, Lemongrass and nutmeg - tough to go wrong!Going back fo sho!

_c1HKS1QIwzhKBglgru37g.text: Was looking for another restaurant Asian restaurant on Wardour Street but google maps failed me, so we ended up on going to Banana Tree.I started with the Lychee Mojito, which I thought was a bit too syrupy. I wish I had gotten a beer. I had the Monk's Tofu dish (vegetarian) which was pretty good - chunks of tofu, fresh vegetables, and good spices. They upsold me on the side of rice that came with a few small appetizers (salad, crispy chips, etc.) which I regretted instantly when it came.Service was spotty and it took forever to get the bill and pay. The decor is very ware-housey urban, which is kind of cool, but just reminds me that the place is another London chain. I most definitely wouldn't return.

O_5BefMdWJhqsbalS1_YXw.text: food looked good though didn't get to try it. service was horrendous. from the wait at the door to get in with 25% of the tables empty, it took 20 mins...sat down and waited another 20 for no attention. walked out and hostess decided to ask why we were leaving.

od-RCdl-xDtW5VJKH4uMZQ.text: 2* might be harsh, but I'll try to justify it.I've had enough authentic Malaysian / SG / Thai food to know whats good and whats bad, though to be fair - I'm not as knowledgeable down to the type of paste / noodle (see Tim L's review from April 17/12), which is very important. I've been here twice: once because we were desperate to eat, and a second time because I was given a voucher to make up for the poor food received from the first time around.First time:Chargrilled blackened chili pork leg, with a combo of glass noodle salad, corn cakes, spicy crackers, steamed Jasmine rice - 8.90 + 3.25 add-on for the combo.  The combo can only be added onto certain dishes - the ones I wanted were all sold out.  The waiter was kind enough to let me have the combo add-on with the pork leg meal, which normally isn't included.  When the dish arrived, I was appalled at the size - I wish I took a picture.  The leg meat was 3 paper thin, dry slices of meat, 2" in diameter.   This made up my £8.90 portion of the meal.  The 3.25 add-on filled me up more than the meat.  I had a word with the waiter about the size, and he apologised - also admitted that because I ADDED on a combo, they decided to cut down my meat portion to make sure I don't waste food, and that its never usually that small.  Excuse me?!  I'm paying extra money for sides, so why is my main portion being cut down?  I should get what I pay for - if there are leftovers, then leave it up to me.  I've paid for it already, so if there are extras, I can take it home.  I was given a voucher to come back a second time. Second time: Ying Yang Laksa with Coriander Meatballs - 8.60Chicken + Shitake money bags - 4.90The laksa was OK - rich spicy broth.  I wouldn't order the money bags again - I felt it was a very poor attempt at making deep fried dumplings.  Overall: + servers were attentive and accommodating when I complained about the size+ nice atmosphere+ value: affordable, considering its the Soho area+ if you HAVEN'T had SE Asian food before, this will probably be a good medley of spices / flavors to get your feet wet, but: - the food isn't authentic at all.  A decent attempt, but you'll get the real flavors and food at a non-chain restaurant- beware when adding on a combo, as I've been told by their manager / kitchen staff that they cut down on the main size.  Not sure if they are still doing this since I complained and said an add-on doesn't give them the right to cut down on a meal size.- my friends had pad thai and Kway teow mee, which were poorly done.  Not enough "wok hay" - a cooking technique using a smoking hot wok, which 100% affects the way food tastes.  lucidmike78.blogspot.co.…Again, if you haven't had this type of food before, it may seem great - but while the atmosphere and vibe here is nice, go somewhere else for authentic food.

6MIp6V_ZOSXyG2FRCSemmw.text: Food was tasty, but my pork belly came out room temperature and tough, so it was definitely a case of pre-cooked food that was reheated...which I assume was not the kept at the right temperature, because I needed to make a fast trip to the toilet before I even left the restaurant. If you go with one of the fried chicken dishes, you can expect a hot dish. That was actually tastier than mine. Rice was also not my favorite...very dry. Ambiance is noisy, and service can be a bit slow to get your order placed.

y6UjlN4gAuCo0XCpxyt3Fw.text: Our family is gluten-free, and BananaTree offers limited but worthwhile GF gems.    The chicken satay, and in particular the peanut sauce, was great and the papaya salad had a nice kick to it.  The server was knowledgable about GF and was attentive.  A small pocket of GF dining in Soho.   One suggestion to BananaTree, include "GF" on your menu like you list Vegetarian.

xp1pcOfW_4TVUktSuHTo3g.text: What a lovely new Soho find.Banana Tree offers Busaba Eathai food at Wagamama prices.  The offerings aren't terribly original, but it's freshly produced and tastes delicious, plus portion sizes are just right (they look small, but they're packed with meat and lovely rich sauces, leaving you just full enough to make it through the afternoon without falling asleep).  Plus by serving side salads on a banana leaf, they ensure it looks beautiful.In fact the food presentation contrasts rather too well with the spartan interior.  It's all exposed pipes, brick walls, concrete benches; that old chestnut. We've seen it before. (Perhaps at Wagamama's).  I suppose it helps to focus our attention on the lovely edibles but nonetheless it just doesn't feel as welcoming as Busaba Eathai.  It's tough not to compare the two when the food on offer is so similar; but in terms of atmosphere, Busaba wins hands down. Banana Tree is certainly more practical (there is actually space between the tables for a pushchair or somebody on crutches; you can see what you're eating; you don't fear that if a fire were to break out, you'd be burnt to a crisp before getting half way across the insanely crowded room), and you can't fault the quality of the food, but it does lack that certain je ne sais quois.On the other hand, this means that you can actually get in and out during your lunch break, which is a bonus. I suspect it won't be the case for long, though; as with most Soho eateries, within a month they'll either be packing up and moving on or have patrons queuing for half a mile down Wardour St.  We're a tough crowd, but by god are we loyal.

UU--H1YeSERaJ1Vf6pKqWg.text: This is the worst Asian restaurant I've ever been to in the world. The past reviews sum it up accurately - service is dreadful here and they're unapologetic about it. We waited over an hour for our meal, which they forgot to tell the kitchen about. When it arrived, the laksa was mostly water and powder - did they run out of noodles or is that just the way they limit portions to the extreme? After that, the bill arrived and the waiter offered us 25% as a gesture to how abysmal the entire experience had been. The manager stepped in to give us 50% after acknowledging that we waited over an hour, and also another 30 minutes to even get the bill. Two hours spent in this place is two hours wasted. Don't bother going here unless every single restaurant is closed in Soho. Opt for next door's Busaba Eathai, Vapiano or Hummus Brothers.

_cVSYKsFqms6X8UnIporQg.text: *breathes out**does a few squats*Ok so as you can see I'm having trouble writing this.I really wanted to be praising this place like a happy monkey on meth  but that isn't the case.Firstly, I was seated and had to yell like a market seller to get anyone to come over and see what I needed.This is no exaggeration. I needed strepsils immediately after. My throat was sore.The food came very quickly. I almost suspect a microwave was involved.Although everything looked amazing, it sadly didn't taste as great.Nom nom nom, I powered through the meal.Then things got so dark. RAW CHICKEN! Dun dun dunnnnnn!I threw myself on the table clutching my neck. Spilling my drink, I kicked and thrust around.Ok maybe I didn't but I did think about it.The manager apologised, put in a new order but as you can imagine that ruined the meal even further as one of us was left hungry and had to wait while the other devoured their meal.Sad times.

9RiMWO01dLfq7CuO0BTKew.text: Went here for a lunch take away. The menu looked really good, the staff were really friendly and guided me through the menu until i found something I wanted to try out. I ordered the chicken pad thai and i wasn't disappointed. It was really fresh and tasted really good.

6iDY_2K6YjHFVgqI8nzYhg.text: We were headed to another place when we stumbled on this restaurant.  We were drawn in by the crowd and then looked at the menu to find that it had Asian inspired cuisine with some unique combinations.  The food turned out to be fresh and refreshing with interesting combinations.  While it is a lively place it is a little noisy which is why it loses a star.  On the plus side, our waitress Matilda did a great job of helping us decide what to have.  We would go there again.

a-swOP9etgHbLX5HsmCz2g.text: I had one of their lunch specials, chicken green curry, which came beautifully presented with jasmine rice and Thai salad.It was tasty, although the curry a little weak and not much chicken. On the other hand veggies were abundant and the overall flavour was very pleasant.I accompanied my meal with fragrant jasmine tea, all for less than 10£, so good value for money and speedy service make this a very good spot for office lunch break.

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Chicken green curry

adYXVUUrekIpQiWqysYKrQ.text: Recently visited the Banana Tree for a team lunch with 12 other people.  They took a reservation which was very useful for a lunch group of that size.The menu has plenty of options to choose from for meat eaters and vegetarians, including an express lunch menu for £5.95.I had the veg spring rolls, tofu green curry with a portion of sticky rice, and a juice.  Presentation was very creative, its always fun eating out of a tiny frying pan, or having small individual rolls of sticky rice.The total bill, including a tip, came to £26.  Although each dish was fragrant and tasty, I found the portions small and unsatisfying, and even though these dishes are on the express menu, we were all still charged the full price menu option.  I shudder to think how small the portions on the express menu must be.The service was very friendly and attentive, if not a bit slow (we were there for 2 hours).  If I am looking for a thai restaurant of this caliber for a group of people whose size requires reservations then I will certainly consider a re visit.  But if I am looking for tasty thai, good portions, and value for money I doubt the Banana Tree will be at the top of my list.

nX4EUKqca4o-fwCOfj3hrA.text: We have been to this branch more these days, because the service is much better than the Islington one.  We always order noodle dishes and they are almost always reliable; but they lack the smokiness of the Wok.  I am still not sure about the rest on the menu; if you want a quick satisfying meal, order some noodles.Their Balinese 'Pulut Hitam' Pudding (Glutinous Rice Pudding) was as good as ever and I strongly recommend to order Banana 'Frotiteroles' (Banana Fritters) without the chocolate sauce.  The service has greatly improved here; the waitresses were very friendly and efficient during our previous 2 visits in March and April.

eh0G3aDA7TszgLm1u7GXog.text: Food here is alright, got the laksa here. Feel like they need a greater variety and range of flavours. Food looks very dark or is black in colour, and sometimes lack flavour, such as their chicken dumplings.I cant help but shake the feeling that this place gives me of amateurism. The ambience and interiors isnt nice. And the service very spotty. Food took a long time to arrive and one starter arrived a lot later than the other. Servers in general look confused

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Chicken wings... Could be higher quality
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Chicken jawa... Herby and alright
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Laksa

oT0i_J6hi7hUOO3s4sGJAw.text: One of the best places I've eaten at in London. Drinks are BOGO so might as well have two!  Definitely try the steamed chicken dumplings. The sauce they are in is exquisite.

5QWA10Cg0HYvvoJy1msqJA.text: Banana Tree is one of those asian/pan european restaurants. When it's done well, you appreciate the twist on classics and staples you've tried in those countries. Where it's done badly, it's just insulting, bordering on embarassing. At one of these type chains in Germany when I complained that a dish I'd had a milllion times was a little salty, I was told this is how it's supposed to taste!Gladly Banana Tree falls into the former category. That said, it's not perfect and there are a few areas it could improve.The interior is great. Spacious, airy, warm and you can see the food being prepped in the kitchen. Great. Service is brisk and polite, if a little stilted.Whenever I go to restaurants like banana tree or giraffe, I like to order things I'm familiar with to compare the quality of the dish. I picked the Thai Tamarind and Garlic Wings along with the double cooked crispy pork mix. These were great. New flavours and concepts for me. The double cooked crispy pork in particular crispy, but still moist inside. There were a few duds however that had obviously been over-fried which we had to leave unfortunately (I think this is the dish that gave me a sore throat afterward!) The achar pickle a little milder than you'd get in an asian household, but tasted great.For the mains, Chicken curry laksa and Kway Teow Mee. The curry laksa was great, lots of ingredients and the chef did make it extra spicy as we'd requested. The Kway Teow Mee however was lacking. The trick with that dish is to have a very high heat in order to char the noodles. This they got half way right. But the noodles should have been flat rice noodles instead of the standard rice noodles they used. Texture is everything.Additionally the Vietnamese coffee we ordered was WAY too sweet. Too much condensed milk and not enough coffee.We were way stuffed after those 2 courses which is a good thing. You won't go hungry on the portions here. However there is just a little work needed on the food to really elevate this place to 5 stars. Everything else from atmosphere, staff and interior is there. One last thing. There is a wifi point called banana tree at the branch, but it's locked and I was told this was for staff use only. That's annoying. If it's for staff only, call it something else. Wifi access is close becoming something every good business should have as standard. If only to upload my photos to Yelp or Instagram asap!

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Curry Laksa
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Kway Teow Mee
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Double Cooked Crispy Pork Mix

RA9ciagDlBXq9P3tCGpyRw.text: Casual Indonesian spot with great randang beef.Food: 4, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 4Cost to worth it rating: 4Return worthiness: yesHighlights:- Large amount of lunch specials from noodles to dishes - Beef randang: waiter said it's the best item on the menu so I had to get it. Stewed enough to be soft and mixed in with the spices but still maintained some full beef pieces. Served with a nice bean sprout salad that had a light sweet dressing. - Juice with mint: nice combination of a few fruits including - Service: waiter was really patient and helpful while we were trying to decideLowlights:- Spicy soup: wasn't as spicy as we would've likedCute place on a cool restaurant street I'd come back to.

NXThI4Et5v33NfQne1lrjw.text: The Wagamama of Indo-Malay-Chinese food, with a good range of options for halal and strict vegetarian diets. Main dishes include a range of meat and vege options: fried noodles, soup noodles, curries and stews. All range from £7 - £11 ish each so pretty good value. We went for the Banana Tree combo - for an extra £3.25 you get a little pile of salad, spicy prawn crackers, rice and little balls of falafel made of sweet corn. Bargain!Food was slightly salty for my liking however full of flavour and tastiness. Good choice of real fruit juices (like Wagamama) and a nice range of cocktails/mocktails. They operate an open kitchen so depending where you're seated you may end up smelling of food!You may be expected to share tables with other diners so bear this in mind if you're looking for some privacy. Overall a good casual place for quick and tasty food.

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Tamarind fish in sweet sauce, with the Banana Tree combo (rice, salad, sweet corn falafel and prawn crackers)

u_rz-QdKxJcfthHascrYFw.text: I really do love the food here, it's very tasty.  Always combo-up.  ALWAYS! They used to have great options for vegans but now it's very limited (where's the mock duck?).  I don't go very often so I don't mind getting the same thing every visit, as it's always a treat.  But I do miss the food variety that was on offer the first few times I went.  I think there's two vegan dishes, but you can only combo-up on one so I always get the aubergine dish. Coz I'm a pig.

v5iTGRUaLjH1I_6cQNqhkg.text: Although it initially appears pricey (many of the prices listed are for dishes are just curries without rice) but what you get is high quality food (tender well-spiced meat) and big portions when you combo up: dishes come with rice, sweet corn cakes, crackers and a side salad for an extra £3.50. We also had the pho which was also top notchAnother plus point is that the menu is very easy for people with allergens, especially people with gluten intolerances as you are spoilt for choice, which you don't often find at restaurants. One negative point is that despite the extremely long happy hour (open til 7pm), the cocktails are a little disappointing tl;dr Great food, good portions, well catered for people with allergies but meh on the cocktail front

jVeQW-6rJGAduDGHylx0Kg.text: It feels fantastic to finally find a gluten-free friendly Asian fusion restaurant, and Banana Tree certainly doesn't disappoint with its wide range of choices. The menu was clear, had a lot of options, and had fairly reasonable prices for a Soho joint.I had the chicken pho, my first since going gluten-free, and the chicken was beautifully juicy and tender, which is always a good sign, and the combo option with the curry that my other half had, was also fantastic, and it was all out rather quickly and was presented beautifully (I was too busy to get a picture).My only real issue was the service: within a minute of sitting down, we were asked if we wanted drinks, having barely even looked at the menu, and then again by a different waiter about 30 seconds later, at which point I almost felt like leaving because of how pushy they were. A third waiter appeared about two minutes later to ask us if we were okay with the menu, once we'd made a decision, and then got confused about our cocktail order. I think it was a fourth waiter that took our order. Later, when we wanted the bill, it took 15 minutes to be able to ask anybody to send us the cheque, so it went from pushy fast to painfully slow. The cocktails were a little disappointing (we had two types, one being a Long Island), but it being an Asian fusion restaurant and not a cocktail bar, it was brilliant enough they even had cocktails, especially as the happy hour seems to run all day!Despite this, I would definitely return, just due to the fact that the allergen info was so clear, and the food so tasty, so don't let that put you off!

fTDseQdAkYUOypCPXQY5Mw.text: Nice atmosphere and tasty dishes. The waitress is fast, knowledgable, and friendly. Great convo. Dimming the light after 8pm and switching the music on gives it a different feel- quite trendy.

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. After 8pm they dim the lights and play music. Quite loud but a great atmosphere.
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. The Legendary Renang with chicken as combo meal. Nice flavor and good spice to it! Recommended!

smTZJT3ir0BXWXns9-RzSQ.text: Wonderful food.  A real gem for the food. Service was OK, but nothing special.  I would go five stars for the food and three for service.   Maybe they need new management in the front of house.

cuakr8TI1bpAQJNiImLz_A.text: Very very busy. Tasty though. The service wasn't the best - very very extremely slow, but I quite understand it as there were only 3 waiters for the whole restaurant...def not enough. Would def go again.

QM68Ce49Lv_6WSGn5UFjqQ.text: I'm always a fan of southeast Asian food and I can tell you that everything they serve here will exceed your expectation. I came here with friends and we tried different things on the menu from starters to main dishes. I really like the ying yang laksa and it comes with a thick and mild spicy broth in coconut milk. It has all the nice herbs including coriander and basil that add up the taste. You can also choose from chicken, meatballs or prawns. I had a bowl of large laksa when it was raining outside so it was perfect.My friends and I shared a couple of starter plates. We had the fried dough that comes with tasty peanut sauce, chicken wings which were well marinated with sweet and sour sauce with basil, and fried Vietnamese spring rolls with sweet ginger dip sauce. Everything was so gooddd. And then I tried some of my friends' dishes like the tamarind fish. They offer you a combo pack, which basically let you have jasmine rice, glass noodles, crispy prawn crackers, and friend meatballs by adding £3.50. It's a good combination and good deal for a big meal. Services were good too and you can tell that this place is popular and it gets really busy at lunch time.

ByXqJZb56GN_SOlbwsFIgQ.text: Very nice place in Soho.They have plenty of Asian food dishes to choose from and also "combo" option useful if you are really really hungry. The rice they offer amongst the sides it's really good and the food in general it's decent. This place does not accept reservations so you might be in for a wait if you show up in weekend during peak times. One thing that might affect negatively your experience at Banana Tree is the sometimes excessive level of noise: my god this place is noisy. Also being a small please doesn't help either, sometimes it's hard to hear even your dinner mates at your table for how noisy this place is. But I guess that the nice food and the quick service make up for it. Just if you are looking for a relaxing and intimate atmosphere this is not what you are looking for.

E-X01Qr_ypk7d7OyXR2DPg.text: Decent South East Asian food, in a casual restaurant, at reasonable prices. Think Wagamamas style, but for South East Asian food.I had the chicken laksa, which is noodles in a creamy curry broth - it was pretty authentic.

oXAOCMANF40faOvS-tKPgw.text: Barring once using a toilet many years ago when filming, I've never set foot in a Banana Tree admittedly out of skepticism having had many disappointing experiences with Asian chains. I have to admit I was wrong, this was great. I ordered the following:- Green Papaya SaladI have long been a fan of green papaya salads and this has everything you would want from one: sourness, chilliness and an overall wonderfully refreshing experience topped with nicely spiced grilled chicken. It came with elegantly wrapped glutinous rice packages which were a bit of a waste of time but other than that, this was thoroughly repeatable.

ZCxb9TQcd_FNVuIwY_IU4A.text: Damn. Accidentally stumbled upon this restaurant with my family and holy crap I'm floored at how good the food was. We killed everything in 20 minutes or less- the laksa, Thai curry were super on point. The Phad Thai had an interesting twist and my family definitely enjoyed it. Best and highest rating I've given so far in London during my 10 days stay here. 10/10 would come back. Also, buy one get one free drink is super nice too- seriously digging this place.

xs0NnkEcz42VHJTOhVlJsQ.text: Pretty decent Thai food, very large portions, friendly and accommodating service.Our table had the Banana Tree Lahksa.  Creamy base, very very generous portion!! I ordered the one that contained all the protein offerings and was not disappointed.  I really enjoyed their take on the pork meatball.  I asked for extra spicy which turned out to not be spicy at all but they gave me this fermented chile on the side that was to. die. for!!  This chile was really the highlight of this restaurant.  My friend had the beef pho which was very underwhelming, lacked flavor, and lacked temperature (the Lahksa did as well).  It's a soup dish, we need these babies to be steaming hot, especially with this bone chilling London weather!!  We also had the chicken satay and pulled duck into wraps.  I give these babies 5 stars for presentation!  Chicken satay was delish, great flavor, and it came with these cute little sticky rice squares wrapped in palm leaf, and a great peanut sauce (easy on the sweetness though, consider it maybe?).  Pulled duck wraps came with all the vegetable fixings with their take on nuoc mam...again, chill with the sweetness, it's supposed to be a savory dipping sawceee.It was a little bit pricey but this is coming from a biased Californian living in Westminster where we are riddled with cheap delicious thai food.

aKwLQUQ8Suy18AczNYkfCA.text: Indochinese restaurant chain with several restaurants all over London. Nice food, decent prices, quick service & industrial interiors.. Recommended if you would like to try something different!

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom

ceDRYy8vlcis0Q7Ra6DvBw.text: Good thai food. Huge portions and friendly and fast service.

0TPyrwSsWit9E4kIQEDdWA.text: Excellent Asian fusion restaurant in the heart of vibrant Wardour St. Good choice of meat and veggie dishes, quick service and reasonably priced.

MXI-5avLW0mA_vC6X5fHWA.text: Another awesome place for asian fusion. Wonderful food. Service is good.Ambiance is OK.Recommended - The BananaTree Laksa

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom

JTzagJ_8fNod8WhhuFwSPg.text: Food: We ordered the sweet and sour crispy chicken, the banana tree special spicy wok noodles, jasmine rice and egg fried rice. The food was OK. The veg in the sweet and sour chicken could be improved. The banana tree special spicy noodles lacked spice. The portion sizes were very large (look at the photo attached). Drink: I only ordered a soft drink, but it was flat. Service: I have been to banana tree several times and each time the place has been understaffed and the staff are often overworked - resulting in forgotten orders or lack of service. Atmosphere: The ambience and atmosphere of the restaurant is very casual and nice. Very lively and quite busy.Price: Very reasonably priced for the amount of food you get, considering it's central London!Banana tree does well to keep good standards of food considering it's an expanding chain!

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom

kiwoaXbuHsT9RnKmw-9vDQ.text: I was meeting a friend from home for a catch-up and she had a Taste Card so we had a nosey on the app and found Banana Tree. The offer was 2-4-1 on starters and mains AND happy hour cocktails... Happy days! I had heard good things about Banana Tree so I was happy to head there and check it out! The restaurant is huge with plenty of table and bar seating. I was annoyingly sat next to these winder leaver things which kept prodding into me so I wouldn't say I was comfortable throughout the evening.We ordered two Woo Woo's which, of course, turned into four. They were fresh tasting but there wasn't much alcohol in there and they went down a little too quickly, mainly because they were filled with ice. I then opted for the steamed chicken dumplings in a fresh herb and garlic sauce - they were served in a bowl and covered in the sauce. I have to say they were pretty good but if I wouldn't have been a big fan of the sauce then they would have been difficult to eat but luckily for me it was YUMMY. Next, I had their recommended Banana Tree Laksa with king prawns - rice noodles topped with a spiced coconut broth, with aubergine & bean sprouts. It was definitely hot. You could really taste the spice in the broth but it was good. There were plenty of prawns and SO MANY noodles. The bowl was huge and no matter how much I ate it just didn't seem to go down. I ended up leaving half of it which is never a bad thing I guess. I did enjoy it and would definitely have it again! Our waitress was friendly but we had to have the bill amended in line with the Taste Card even though we'd mentioned it twice and when actually asking for the bill.Overall our experience was good, it was just a shame about the few irritants but I would go again for a cheapish and satisfying meal if needed.

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Chicken dumplings
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Prawn Banana Alaska

iDyomyQmIjqQqG9GCuvidg.text: Okay food.One thing to note though:If they ever ask you if you would like some prawn crackers after taking your order, just note it is NOT FREE! I think customers would appreciate if you explicitly mention it is not a complimentary item.

rQkMOCErvlh-E0KRBzPECQ.text: We were here in our first Londonese night after at hopping and even as drunk as we were the food was delicious We were back on our last night and sober and did not get disappointed .., the laksa soup still was good as the first time ...

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom

Aua0TJYxjUQJDLY4zqh5EA.text: What I liked the best about this place is they have a holding pen to corral all their customers who are waiting for tables. Not only that, they will bring you drinks!We had noodles and a grilled pork dish which were underwhelming at best. It tasted ok but I'll hardly be running back. But their wait staff are all friendly and on top of things which goes a long way!

TkqvjXJfT-vgUt4vO8-Gzw.text: Delicious food and fast and nice service. The chicken dumplings were unbelievable, and the special beef curry was also delicious. Highly recommend this place.

q4CaR-M4kb61oxH07LTa5w.text: Soooooooooo guess who was swinging on a banana tree the other night? NOT ME! ... I was at the restaurant mate.So it reminded me a little of wagamama/busaba so I thought I'd finally see what the fuss was all about. I found the menu very limited in my opinion . Anyhoo, I ordered the grilled chicken with fragrant rice. It had a much more exotic name than that but I'll be damned if I can recall it! I also ordered their sticky tamarind chicken wings..oh yes it was a chicken fiesta baby! So the wings were very tasty in my books! Could've had a little more of a crisp to them but flavour wise it was on point! Now as for my main course.... Drum roll..... Disappointing It looked a lot better than the taste .. It was so lightly seasoned I wasn't sure the chicken was even dead! The rice was yellow just for the fun of it because there was nothing fragrant about it really... Ahhhhh would I go back? Nahhh but it hit the spot at the time so I should be grateful right haha

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Those wings deserve their own monument!

vlg5in-wJ9JMXh_VeRv4Yg.text: my first time at this restaurant . The food was ok , but service a bit disappointed . Few people was taking orders from us , so I was not sure who is my server . To order another drink I have to grab someone attention. Good offer for cocktails between 5-7pm buy one get another free. A bit noisy ass well

UwE5aBW-oz6835D8DQI2mw.text: Yummy, quick, flavourful and good value.  I'm going back!The Good:*Signature dishes were well prepared.  Flavourful, well-portioned, and reminiscent of true Indochina cuisine.  The Lahksa had an amazing coconut milk base, and was complimented by many spices, the noodles, and freshly prepared prawns.  It hit the spot on a cold London evening.*We were seated right away (w/o a reservation), which is saying something, given the pretentious nature of a few of the SoHo eating establishments nearby.The Bad:*Two-for-One Happy Hour special drinks.  Right?  Right?  (Sigh)  First taste was 100% alcohol, and cheap stuff at that.  After some of the ice melted, the drinks tasted like water, lacking flavour.  But for the fresh passion fruit on top, these drinks were deplorable.  The Ugly:Server was on his first day (and not as a trainee) and didn't have full knowledge of the menu, so special requests caused delay and confusion.Overall, their signature dishes are amazing!  We'd go back for the food.  Good prices as well makes this a winner for an exotic early dinner before a show-

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Signature Dish: Banana Tree Lahksa

ZseuvBB9V1XYkMaFUKBH0w.text: Banana Tree is in an awesome area surrounded by lots of shops and other restaurants so it was a nice treat to walk past. The menu looked exciting but upon walking in, there was a stale smell and it was not full compared to other restaurants nearby. Nonetheless, I was craving some fragrant and strong flavours and Banana Tree is an IndoChinese restaurant guaranteed to provide those flavours! They have some nice starters, soups, curries, salads, meats with salad and some cool drinks. We ordered the Duck Spring Rolls and it was recommended we wrap them in lettuce, mint, coriander, some pickled carrots and dip it in a spicy sauce (Recommended as in they put a little card on our plate to tell us how to eat it- Bit random). It sounds all very exciting but I preferred it separately. The pickled carrots were awesome! We also ordered steamed chicken dumplings which were awesome!! For mains I had the Laksa soup - IT WAS MASSIVE!!! For only £10.95 I believe! But it is extremely rich. It's a pretty relaxed vibe and the waiters/waitresses are all pretty chilled too. Super affordable and nice if you want a spicy dish or a big variety.

x1W3XKHGt7BCPDhNkUFLTQ.text: After eating English style fish and chips mostly during my vacation in London. My sister and I were craving some good Asian cuisine. Bad itinerary planning on my part, (went to London, then went to Paris then went back to London lol I just wanted to make my sister more adventurously tired) our train arrived to London from Paris in the evening for the last 2 days of our trip.  By the time we put our luggage away and did some  shopping near the oxford and regent street it was dinner time. We walked/ or took the train towards the west side of London. I was so tired that night not sure how we ended up in soho, London. Very lively place with bars and contemporary restaurants. And I wasn't sure why they had so many sex related stores etc. Later, I researched about it and discovered soho was one naughty place up to 1980s. The point is we found an amazing Asian restaurant called Banana Tree. They have 6 locations in U.K. Only have been to this location and it was very no fuss hip sort of restaurant with regular seating as well as communal seating.We ordered two mocktails (yummy/yummy) from their extensive mocktails/juice list. The appetizer noodle soup we ordered was amazing with a delicious curry flavor to it. We ordered two noodle dishes as well and they were unique and tasteful. The service was quick and efficient and I liked the casual date night atmosphere. If your in London go to one of their locations for sure (this one is for you Ash and your upcoming trip to Europe)

photos.caption: Photo of Banana Tree - London, United Kingdom. Some food and mocktails :)

lwB9Yx7ScnW0r70A7ig-tw.text: Some of the worst asian food I've ever had. I ordered an Ayam Kunyit Chicken curry for lunch. The chicken tasted like it had been frozen and thawed, definitely not fresh. The little sauce it was in was so watered down and devoid of all flavor. Super disappointed.
